delimiter_settings="delimiter_style:solid|delimiter_width:0|delimiter_height:1" undefined="" title_font_options="tag:h2|color:%23000000|font_style_bold:1" subtitle_font_options="tag:h5|color:%23000000|font_style_bold:1"]

Understanding Your

Estate Plan

[/dfd_heading][dfd_spacer screen_wide_spacer_size="20" screen_normal_resolution="1024" screen_tablet_resolution="800" screen_mobile_resolution="480" screen_normal_spacer_size="15" screen_tablet_spacer_size="15" screen_mobile_spacer_size="10"][vc_column_text]A Power of Attorney is one of the most important documents you can have in place in the event you are unable to care for yourself. The document acts as a permission slip, giving authority to someone else to do things on your behalf when you cannot do them yourself.  A Power of Attorney for Financial Management means someone else can legally spend your money. A Power of Attorney for Healthcare gives someone else the authority to make critical medical decisions for you.  Learn how to make sure that you understand these powerful documents and be sure that they are doing what you want them to do for you.  Also, learn how to review your current trust to see if it needs to be updated to conform to changes in the law.   Julie Cho, Esq. has over 20 years of experience as a Trust and Estate Attorney. She has counseled both individuals and small businesses in matters involving estate planning, business litigation, business planning and general counsel services.  For more information see https://juliecholaw.com/[/vc_column_text][dfd_spacer screen_wide_spacer_size="20" screen_normal_resolution="1024" screen_tablet_resolution="800" screen_mobile_resolution="480" During this period of the COVID-19 pandemic, you are encouraged

to consider making a donation of $10 or $15 to support

the Los Angeles Chapter - AAII ongoing expenses.

To donate you may (CLICK HERE). Thank You!

item.excerpt:encoded: Financial Education meeting information that focuses on the broad overview of basic individual investing in today's market.
